findings.rationale: The perpetual and exclusive license may allow the employer to use the employee's work product indefinitely without additional compensation, which could lead to exploitation of the employee's creativity.
findings.evidence_quote: Provider grants Employer a perpetual, exclusive license to use all work product created during employment for Employer's business purposes.

findings.rationale: A 3-year confidentiality obligation post-termination may limit the employee's ability to work in their field and could be seen as overly restrictive.
findings.evidence_quote: Confidentiality obligations survive termination and continue for 3 years.

findings.rationale: A 1-year non-compete clause within the same industry may significantly hinder the employee's future employment opportunities.
findings.evidence_quote: Employee may not compete within the same industry for 1 year after termination, within Employer's service area.

findings.rationale: The ability for either party to terminate the agreement with only 30 days notice may create instability and uncertainty for the employee.
findings.evidence_quote: Either party may terminate for convenience with 30 days written notice.

findings.rationale: Capping indemnification at annual compensation may leave the employee vulnerable to significant claims or liabilities beyond their salary.
findings.evidence_quote: Mutual indemnification: each party indemnifies the other for its own negligence, capped at annual compensation.
